input: An adult male presents with persistent complaints of palpable lumps, night sweats, and fatigue over several weeks to months. He reports these symptoms are affecting his sleep and energy levels and expresses significant emotional distress. Physical symptoms are likely ongoing, but the perceived severity may be amplified by his emotional response. Further assessment is needed to clarify the actual impact on daily functioning, identify any additional associated symptoms, and explore underlying emotional or psychological factors.1. Diagnosis: Hodgkin lymphoma Justification: Persistent palpable lumps (likely lymph nodes), night sweats, fatigue, and emotional distress are classic B-symptoms of lymphoma, especially Hodgkin type; this is a common lymphoid malignancy in adults presenting with systemic “B” symptoms.  2. Diagnosis: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma Justification: Similar presentation with lymphadenopathy, systemic symptoms, and fatigue; more diverse in presentation, but still highly probable given the systemic signs.  3. Diagnosis: Tuberculosis lymphadenitis (scrofula) Justification: Chronic lymph node enlargement with systemic symptoms like night sweats and fatigue suggests infectious causes, especially tuberculosis, common in latent or active TB exposure.  4. Diagnosis: Infectious mononucleosis Justification: Palpable lymphadenopathy, fatigue, and systemic symptoms are typical, especially in young to middle-aged adults; may cause prolonged symptoms and lymphoid hyperplasia.  5. Diagnosis: Sarcoidosis Justification: Granulomatous disease presenting with chronic lymphadenopathy, fatigue, and systemic symptoms; often involves thoracic lymph nodes but can involve other sites.  6. Diagnosis: Chronic viral infections (e.g., HIV) Justification: HIV can cause generalized lymphadenopathy, fatigue, and systemic symptoms; also emotional distress correlates with chronic illness.  7. Diagnosis: Leukemia (e.g., chronic lymphocytic leukemia) Justification: Fatigue and lymphadenopathy are common; systemic symptoms often develop over time, sometimes associated with emotional distress due to diagnosis.  8. Diagnosis: Castleman disease Justification: Rare lymphoproliferative disorder presenting with enlarged lymph nodes, systemic symptoms like night sweats, fatigue, and sometimes constitutional symptoms.  9. Diagnosis: Reactive lymphadenopathy due to autoimmune disease Justification: Conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or lupus can cause persistent lymph node enlargement and systemic symptoms, often associated with autoimmune activity.  10. Diagnosis: Psychological/psychiatric causes (somatic symptom disorder) Justification: Emotional distress and perceived severity might amplify symptom perception; however, palpable lumps need further pathological explanation to rule out physiological causes. This diagnosis accounts for systemic features and localized orbital signs.  4. These conditions tend to produce painless or painful orbital masses with systemic signs and are considered in differential diagnoses of orbital masses with systemic features.  5. Diagnosis: Idiopathic Orbital Inflammatory Syndrome (Orbital Pseudotumor) Justification: This condition can produce painful, tender orbital swelling with systemic symptoms of malaise and fatigue.
